review.title: Grammatical Case Based IS-A Relation Extraction with Boosting for Polish
review.abstract: Pattern-based methods of IS-A relation extraction rely heavily on so called Hearst patterns. These are ways of expressing instance enumerations of a class in natural language. While these lexico-syntactic patterns prove quite useful, they may not capture all taxonomical relations expressed in text. Therefore in this paper we describe a novel method of IS-A relation extraction from patterns, which uses morpho-syntactical annotations along with grammatical case of noun phrases that constitute entities participating in IS-A relation. We also describe a method for increasing the number of extracted relations that we call pseudo-subclass boosting which has potential application in any pattern-based relation extraction method. Experiments were conducted on a corpus of about 0.5 billion web documents in Polish language.

sections.heading: A. POS tagging and dependency parsing
sections.text: For part of the speech output, we use the Apache OpenNLP (http: / / opennlp.apache.org) tagger, which was trained with the Maximum Entropy Classifier on the NKJP [19] corpus. In addition, we have optimized the tag disambiguation process for known words by narrowing tags that can be selected by information from the PoliMorf dictionary [20]. For the Polish language, whose tagset contains about 1000 tags [21], this simple optimization leads to an improvement in tagging in terms of accuracy and processing speed at the same time. To give an example, the word artykułów (the inflected form of the word article) has only two possible tags subst: pl: gen: m3 and subst: pl: gen: p3.

sections.heading: E. Final filtering rules
sections.text: It is common for NP1 to contain references to earlier parts of the text. As long as this reference is explicit, we filter such cases with a dictionary of referencing words (pronouns and text references as mentioned above). The case in which references are implicit is much more difficult and left here for further research, as described later in Section VI.

sections.heading: III. EXPERIMENTS
sections.text: The experiments were carried out on a corpus of about 0.5 billion web documents in Polish with about 11 billion sentences. Tables II, III and V show the results of passing on the entire collection through the method evaluated in Section II. The method evaluation was performed for four levels of the value of t, which, as already described, is the minimum IS-A relation, where TP is the number of relationships evaluated correctly and FP is the number of relationships evaluated incorrectly. Tables II, III and IV show the results of these experiments. Column nom contains the number of unique ISA relations obtained only from nominative constructs.

sections.heading: IV. RELATION TO HEARST PATTERNS
sections.text: To compare our method with the most popular approach, we implemented the Hearst pattern extraction algorithm as follows: • Recognize the enumerating phrase R (one of "taki jak," "taki jak na przykład," "taki jak np.") in a sentence, based on the lexical constructions proposed in [9]. • Check whether words from R to the end of the sentence form a comma-separated list of phrases (the last element is either separated by a conjunction: "i" or "oraz"). The list is assumed to represent distances of a class. • Recognize the class name in words of R with a conditional random field model [26]. Words in this part of the sentence are marked with either "1" or "0." The sequence of "1" closest to R is assumed to represent the class.

There is a lot of specific, domain-specific taxonomic information that is rare in textual resources accessible on the Internet. Of course, pseudo-subclasses do not give a boost when t = 1 and do not affect precision, because we simply accept everything that happens to the final filter rules. sections.heading: VI. FUTURE WORK
sections.text: It is planned to adapt selected coreference resolution methods to our BigData environment and verify their effectiveness with increasing precision of our extraction method. We plan to achieve better detection of phrase beginnings / endpoints by replacing the construction rules described in Section II-D with conditional random field classifiers trained in our experiment with manually annotated correct phrase boundaries. Of course, creating such gold standard sentences with IS-A relationships is more time consuming than the approach proposed in this paper.

sections.heading: VII. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: This paper introduces a novel method of IS-A relation extraction from Polish patterns, which differs from the much-loved Hearst patterns and is applicable in inflected languages with free word order. Thanks to this method, we have been able to extract knowledge that cannot be expressed in enumeration constructs defined by Hearst. In addition, a method for increasing relation extraction is being introduced. As mentioned above, it has potential application in any pattern-based IS-A relation extraction method thanks to its simplicity. Experiments have shown that the algorithm achieves a satisfactory precision 9 (although there is room for improvement) and is capable of generating a high number of taxonomic relationships, making it a valuable input source for any taxonomic induction task. Needless to say, the experiments described in this paper do not provide a complete statistical overview of millions of IS-A relationships, which are concentrated from the cortical analysis of the polarity document we present on such Internet assessment.
